Graphical abstract Hollow ZSM-5 was successfully fabricated using a tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) hydrothermal treatment with an “dissolution-recrystallization” process. The side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline with formaldehyde was studied on a series of cesium modified ZSM-5 catalysts. Among these catalysts, Cs2O/Cs-hollow ZSM-5 (Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5) was found to be the most effective catalyst, which exhibited not only the highest 2-picoline conversion (50.1 %), but also the highest TOF value (2.557 h−1) and the lowest Ea (39.7 kJ mol−1). Meanwhile, the Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst exhibited excellent reaction durability, which was related to the hollow structure of ZSM-5. In addition, the possible 2-picoline side-chain alkylation reaction pathways over cesium modified hollow ZSM-5 catalysts were proposed. The results of this study suggested that cesium modified hollow ZSM-5 is a promising candidate as a catalyst for the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation with formaldehyde in industrial applications. Keywords Hollow ZSM-5 2-Picoline Side-chain alkylation 2-Vinylpyridine 1 Introduction 2-Vinylpyridine (2-VP) is an important vinyl monomer containing a nitrogen heteroatom. Its homopolymers and copolymers have wide applications in many fields, including photochemistry, ion exchange resins, and self-assembling materials [1–6]. The addition product of 2-(2-methoxy-ethyl) pyridine from 2-VP and methanol is used as the veterinary anthelminitic [7,8]. Consequently, a number of processes for making 2-VP monomer have been investigated, such as autoclaving of acetylene with acrylonitrile, oxidative dehydrogenation of 2-ethylpyridine (2-EP) and co-cyclization of methyl cyano ethyl with acetylene [9–11]. Currently, the conventional route for the large-scale production of 2-VP is based on a two-step procedure, which involves a base catalyzed addition of 2-picoline to formaldehyde to give 2-(2-hydroxy ethyl) pyridine followed by dehydration to 2-VP monomer [12,13]. However, due to the growing demand of 2-VP, developing alternative routes is necessary. Side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline with formaldehyde is a potential alternative to produce 2-VP by one-step, which showed simple process than the conventional route. Catalyst development is needed to enable the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation. Towards the development of side-chain alkylation catalysts, research studies mainly focus on alkali exchanged zeolites. ZSM-5 could offer a tunable acidity, shape selectivity, and hydrothermal stability, leading to their use in the process of side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline [14,15]. Previous research indicated that alkali metal modified ZSM-5 catalyst, such as KZSM-5, RbZSM-5, CsZSM-5 and KCsZSM-5 seem effective for 2-picoline side-chain alkylation [9,16,17]. However, the narrow channels of common ZSM-5 zeolites limited the diffusion of reactants and products. Besides, acid sites on the outer surface can lead to undesired side reactions [18–23]. In recent years, hollow zeolites have attracted increasing attention for their applications as supports of catalysts, because of their well-defined hollow structure, thermal/mechanical stability and large external surface. Furthermore, the hollow zeolites exhibit superior performance in the protection of active site. Wang et al. [24] synthesized the ZSM-5 hollow microspheres by one-step method, and the sample showed exceptional conversion of methanol to aromatics and long catalytic lifetime in methanol-to-aromatics process. Dai et al. [25] reported that hollow ZSM-5 showed excellent catalytic performance in the biphenyl methylation reaction. In our previous work, it was found that the cavity structures of hollow ZSM-5 could enhance the catalytic activity and stability of the catalysts in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x [26]. However, there was none report on hollow ZSM-5 as containers of catalysts for the reaction of side-chain alkylation. Herein, we designed the hollow ZSM-5 single crystal and modified it with cesium for the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation with formaldehyde. This was the first report on application for the hollow ZSM-5 materials in side-chain alkylation reaction. The prepared Cs-modified hollow ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited remarkably higher catalytic activity and excellent durability than conventional Cs-ZSM-5 catalyst in the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of hollow ZSM-5 Hollow ZSM-5 was synthesized by TPAOH treatment. In a typical synthesis, parent HZSM-5 (purchased from Nankai University, Si/Al = 38) zeolite was added to 0.15 M TPAOH aqueous solution (10 mL of solution per gram of zeolite). The mixture was placed in a Teflon autoclave and heated at 170 °C for 72 h. The resulting solid was recovered by centrifugation, washed with distilled water, and dried overnight at 80 °C. Finally, the template was removed by calcination in air at 540 °C for 6 h. The resultant hollow ZSM-5 was denoted as hZSM-5. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Cs modified catalysts The resultant hollow ZSM-5 was ion-exchanged with aqueous solution of CsOH (99.9 %, Aldrich) according to conventional exchange procedures. Typically, a catalyst was prepared as follows: hollow ZSM-5 was exchanged at 90 °C for 4 h with a 0.25 M solution of cesium ion (solid/liquid ratio, 10 g/50 mL). The solid was separated from the slurry by centrifugation and washed with excess pure water. The material was then dried in flowing air at 100 °C overnight. The ion-exchange process was repeated three times. The resultant samples were calcined at 540 °C for 6 h under a dry air flow. The Cs+ exchanged hollow ZSM-5 was denoted as Cs-hZSM-5. Some of the Cs-hZSM-5 samples were impregnated with the aqueous solutions of CsOH. After drying overnight at 100 °C, the product was calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h. The modified Cs-hZSM-5 was denoted as Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5. The theoretical loading of Cs2O was 1.0 wt%. For comparison, Cs modified solid ZSM-5 samples were also prepared with above methods, which denoted as Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiment was recorded on a Bruker AXS-D8 Advance powder diffractometer with monochromatic detector equipped with CuK α radiation. The samples were scanned from 2 θ of 5−60° with a step size of 0.02°. N2 adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out at - 196 °C with a surface analyzer (Micrometrics, ASAP 2020). The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded with Tecnai G2 F20. The samples were dispersed into alcohol before observation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained on a Hitachi S-5500 instrument with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV. The elemental compositions of catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, OPTIMA-3000). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on Escalab 250 (Thermo Fisher VG) with a monochromatic X-ray source of Al Kα under ultra-high vacuum (2.4 × 10−8 Pa). The deconvolution method of XPS spectra was fitted by Gaussian function. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments of NH3 and CO2 were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem2920 instrument in a quartz reactor with a TCD as detector. 0.1 g of the sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in an Ar flow at 30 mL min−1, then cooled to 100 °C and saturated with 5% NH3/Ar. After that, the sample was purged with argon for ca. 60 min to remove physically adsorbed ammonia and NH3-TPD was carried out in the range of 100−700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. CO2-TPD measurements were conducted the same as NH3-TPD, and the absorption gas was pure CO2. The constraint index (CI) test was conducted in a fixed-bed micro-reactor. A mixture of 50 mol% n-hexane and 50 mol% 3-methylpentane was used as the mixed reactants. A sample weight of 0.5 g was employed, corresponding to the WHSV of 1.0 h−1 and reaction temperature of 330 °C in the N2 flow at atmosphere pressure. The products were analyzed using on-line gas chromatography (HP5890) with a 50 m HP-PLOT/Al2O3 “S” capillary column and FID detector. The CI was calculated by the following equation: CI = log (1- Xnhexane ) log (1- X3-methylpentane ) where X denotes the fractional conversion of each species. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The prepared catalyst (5.0 g) was packed into a stainless steel tubular fixed-bed reactor with 1.5 cm inner diameter, and it was activated in situ in dry N2 flow at 430 °C for 1 h before use. After decreasing the temperature to 320 °C, a liquid mixture of 2-picoline and formaldehyde with a molar ratio of 1 : 1 was pumped into the reactor at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 1.0 h−1 with N2 at a flow rate of 30 mL min-1. Qualitative and quantitative analysis of the reaction products were performed using the gas chromatograph (GC, HP-5890) equipped with an HP-PLOT-Q column. The conversion of 2-picoline (C2-P), product selectivity (Si), and product yield (Yi) were estimated by the following equations: C 2 - P ( % ) = ∑ yi, o y2-p, o +∑ yi, o × 100 Si ( % ) = yi, o ∑ yi, o × 100 Yi (%) = C2-P× 100 where y2-p, o and yi, o are the outlet molar fraction of 2-picoline and reaction products respectively. The deactivation parameter kd was estimated by the following equation: kd = ln 100- x end x end - ln 100- x in x in t where t is the reaction time (h), xend is the 2-picoline conversion at end of reaction, xin is the initial 2-picoline conversion. Turnover frequency (TOF) is defined as the number of 2-picoline molecules converted per unit molar quantity of Cs per hour. TOFs = [2-P]in C2-p Vin nCs [ h-1 ] where [2-P]in is the concentration of 2-picoline in the inlet; C2-p, the conversion of 2-picoline within the differential kinetic regime (2-picoline conversion below ∼ 15 %, 1 g catalyst was diluted with quartz sand); Vin, the total molar flow rate; nCs, the molar quantity of Cs per gram of the catalysts. The apparent activation energy (Ea) is determined from Arrhenius plots. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity for 2-picoline side-chain alkylation Fig. 1 a and b showed the variations in 2-picoline conversion and 2-vinylpyridine selectivity as a function of time on stream (TOS). It can be seen that almost no 2-picoline conversion was observed over pure HZSM-5 zeolite, indicating that the support themselves were nearly inert for the 2-picoline side-chain alkylation reaction. Among the catalysts, Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 demonstrated the highest 2-picoline conversion and 2-VP selectivity. A maximum 2-picoline conversion of 50.1 % can be achieved on Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 with 2-VP selectivity of 62.5 % (TOS =4 h). As shown in Table 1 , 2-ethylpyridine can be formed as the major byproduct during this side chain process, which influenced the selectivity of 2-VP. It should be noted that the Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst exhibited higher 2-picoline conversion than Cs-ZSM-5 during the entire 10 h (Fig. 1a), which indicated that the hollow structure of ZSM-5 led to a significant promoting effect on the catalytic activity. As the Cs+ loading was increased by the additional introduction of Cs2O on Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs-hZSM-5, both the 2-picoline conversions and 2-VP selectivity increased. It could be inferred that the catalytic activity of the catalysts was influenced by both the hollow structure of ZSM-5 and additional introduction of Cs2O. It is remarkable that the Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 samples had only slightly larger Cs+ contents than that in Cs-hZSM-5 and Cs-ZSM-5 (Table 2 ), but showed substantial differences in catalytic performances. The results indicated that the addition of minor amounts of free Cs2O clusters in catalysts plays a significant catalytic role in the 2-picoline side-chain alkylation. Song et al. [11] proposed the synergistic effect of cesium ions and cesium oxide in side-chain alkylation of toluene with methanol, which indicated that cesium ions could activate toluene, whereas cesium oxide would promote the methanol dehydrogenate to formaldehyde. As the activity results, we inferred that the Cs2O might be beneficial to formaldehyde activation in this reaction. In addition, the catalytic performance over all the catalysts decreased gradually with time on stream for 10 h. Nevertheless, the samples with hollow structure showed better durability than the others. In order to study the activation energies (Ea) and further elucidate the catalytic capacity of each Cs-modified catalyst, Arrhenius plots and 2-picoline turnover frequency (TOF) versus the reaction temperature were obtained and shown in Fig. 1 c and d. The TOF values at 320 °C were ranked as follows: Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 (2.557 h−1) > Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 (2.155 h−1) > Cs-hZSM-5 (1.881 h−1) > Cs-ZSM-5 (1.454 h−1) (Table 1). Meanwhile, the order of Ea was that Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 (39.7 kJ mol-1) < Cs-hZSM-5 (47.8 kJ mol-1) < Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 (48.1 kJ mol-1) < Cs-ZSM-5 (50.1 kJ mol-1). Among these catalysts, Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 exhibited the highest TOF and the lowest Ea, which further revealed that the Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst was more efficient in the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation than other catalysts. 3.2 The transport effect In order to make sure that the obtained kinetic data (Ea and TOF) were not significantly influenced by interphase or intra-particle transfer limitations, the transport effects over Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst were investigated by using Madon-Boudart criterion [44]. The interphase diffusion limitation can be overcome by increasing the flow rate in continuous fixed-bed plug flow reactors at constant weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) until the reaction rate becomes a constant. Herein, the effect of interphase heat and mass transport was experimentally evaluated by employing different flow rates of reactants at constant WHSV of 1.0 h−1. Fig. 2 a showed that there was no significant change in 2-picoline conversion by varying the flow rate of reactants (> 5 mL/h). Thus, the interphase diffusion limitation can be excluded at a feed flow rate of 6 mL/h during the reaction in this study. The particle size of catalyst plays a major role in intra-particle diffusion. The most effective method of avoiding intra-particle diffusion in fixed-bed is to reduce the catalyst particle size. If there is no internal diffusion limitation, the conversion of 2-picoline should be the same. Fig. 2 b showed the variation of 2-picoline conversion with the different particle sizes of Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst, where no significant change in the 2-picoline conversion was observed in the range of 150−200 μm of the particle size. Thus, the effect of internal diffusion limitation can be excluded in the experimental range. 3.3 Catalyst characterization 3.3.1 XRD and BET results Hollow ZSM-5 had the similar crystalline structure as parent ZSM-5 (Fig. 3 ). For the Cs-modified catalysts, all of the XRD patterns exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZSM-5, indicating that the framework of ZSM-5 zeolite was well preserved upon modification of Cs. However, some of the decreases in the relative diffraction peak intensities were observed by comparing the XRD patterns of cesium-modified samples with pure ZSM-5. It was due to the incorporation of cesium, which probably changed the structure factors or X-ray absorption coefficients of the parent [27–29]. Meanwhile, the framework of zeolites might be slightly damaged in the process of ion-exchange or impregnation [11]. It is worth noting that no diffraction peaks corresponding to Cs2O phase can be observed, which may be due to the diffraction peak overlapping of ZSM-5 and Cs2O at about 25°. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of hollow ZSM-5 showed the presence of a H2 hysteresis loop with an abrupt step around P/P0 = 0.42 in the desorption branch (Fig. 4 a). The H2-type hysteresis, not seen in the parent ZSM-5, was a result of voids in the interior of the crystals that can only be accessed via entrances smaller than 4 nm, suggesting a relatively intact outer surface [26]. The enhanced N2 uptake at high P/P0 was associated with capillary condensation of nitrogen within the voids of the zeolite crystal interior, also confirmed the formation of hollow structure. After introducing Cs, the N2 adsorption isotherms were almost the same as those of ZSM-5 and hollow ZSM-5, respectively (Fig. 4b). This further confirmed that the Cs modification did not affect the hollow structure of ZSM-5. Table 2 lists textural properties of the samples. It was found that the hollow ZSM-5 possessed higher BET surface area (SBET) of 441 m2 g−1 than solid ZSM-5 (374 m2 g-1). Besides, Cs-hZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 also possessed higher BET surface area than Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5, resulting from the hollow structure of ZSM-5. The micropore volume (Vmicro) of the ZSM-5 showed almost no change after the TPAOH treatment, while the total pore volume increased from 0.24 to 0.41 cm3/g. It suggested that the original micropore structure in ZSM-5 was not destoried and the mesoporous increased during the dissolution-recrystallization process, which could shorten the diffusion path length, allowing the reactants to reach the active sites more easily and also facilitating the products to diffuse out of the catalyst. By cesium modification, the BET surface area (SBET), micropore volume (Vmicro), and total pore volume (Vtotal) were all decreased to a different extent. The BET surface area of Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs-hZSM-5 decreased about 20 % and 19 % compared with ZSM-5 and hZSM-5, respectively. It indicated that partial H+ were substituted by Cs+ because the radius of the Cs+ was much larger than that of the H+. By further cesium impregnation, the BET surface area of Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 decreased more dramatically (reduced about 35 % and 30 % compared with ZSM-5 and hZSM-5, respectively). The constraint index (CI) is an effective method to determine the porous diffusion-constraint of zeolites, based on the cracking reaction of probe molecules [46]. Thus the prepared samples in this work were characterized by CI determination. As list in Table 2, the parent ZSM-5 showed a CI value of 7.2, while the significantly decreased CI value was obtained for hZSM-5 (4.5). This indicated the TPAOH etching treatment indeed widen the pore-opening of ZSM-5. 3.3.2 TEM and SEM results SEM and TEM were employed to characterize the morphologies and porous structure of the parent and modified samples. Parent ZSM-5 in Fig. 5 a showed a monodispersed solid crystal, which has regular morphology and uniform size with dimensions of 140 nm × 230 nm. After alkali treatment, a hollow structure with a microporous shell was created in the interior of the ZSM-5 (Fig. 5b), which was in agreement with the N2 adsorption-desorption results. Besides, the Cs modified catalysts have the morphology similar to that of corresponding supports (as show in Fig. S1). The HRTEM image of the hollow ZSM-5 showed that the shell is highly crystallized with lattice d-spacing of 9.9 and 9.7 Å (Fig. 5c), commendably matched with d 020 (9.950 Å) and d 111 (9.711 Å) of ZSM-5, respectively [30]. Moreover, the hollow ZSM-5 is still single crystal, as revealed by the Fourier transform of Fig. 5 c (Fig. 5 d). According to the SEM images (Fig. S2), both solid ZSM-5 and hollow ZSM-5 exhibited smooth external surfaces, which indicated that the shells of hollow ZSM-5 are intact. 3.3.3 Acid-base properties of the Cs-modified catalysts Acid-base properties of the catalysts were analyzed using NH3 and CO2-TPD, respectively (Fig. 6 a and b). The quantified amounts of acid and base sites are summarized in Table 3 . For NH3-TPD results, both ZSM-5 and hZSM-5 showed two NH3 desorption peaks, indicating the existence of two kinds of acid sites on these supports. The desorption peak at temperatures lower than 300 °C was associated with weakly acidic silanol groups and weak Lewis (or Brønsted) acid sites [31], while the desorption peak ranged from 300 to 600 °C was associated with the stronger acid sites [32]. Notably, the NH3 desorption peak temperature of hZSM-5 was lower than ZSM-5, which indicated the acid strength was weakened after TPAOH treatment. As the Cs introduced to the ZSM-5 zeolite via Cs+ ion exchange and additional Cs2O loading, the acid sites were diminished. Moreover, the peaks at high temperature almost disappeared, indicating that available strong acid sites are blocked by Cs species. The decreased acidity should be attributed to the exchange of H+ with Cs+ and the formation of Cs2O species [28]. Fig. 6 b showed the CO2-TPD curves of different samples. It can be seen that all the samples showed a pronounced CO2 desorption peak ranged from 140 to 200 °C, which can be attributed to the framework oxygen atoms with negative charge (O δ- ) in the zeolite [34,35]. ZSM-5 showed the weak CO2 desorption peaks at 142 °C, while both the peak area and desorption temperature slightly increased after alkali treatment. As the introduction of Cs, the CO2 desorption temperature further increased, indicating the enhancement of base strength by Cs species modified. Notably, Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 showed another peak at around 370 °C, which was associated with the stronger base sites created on cesium oxide [36,37]. To further clarify the relationship between acid-base property and activity, the dependence of 2-picoline conversion and 2-VP selectivity on the amount of acid sites and base sites was investigated (Fig. 7 ). As shown in Fig. 7a, Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 showed the least amounts of acid sites of 15 μ mol g−1 and contrarily the highest side-chain alkylation activity, which was observed in Fig. 1. It inferred that the increased acid sites not favor the reaction. This might be similar with toluene side-chain alkylation reaction: the acid sites adsorbing 2-picoline should be moderate, otherwise it will catalyze ring alkylation [33]. Fig. 7 b showed that both the 2-picoline conversion and 2-VP selectivity monotonically increased with the increasing amount of base sites, which implied that the basicity played important role in determining the overall catalytic activities of Cs-modified catalysts. To further investigate the role of acid and base site, we conducted the experiments of selective acid-base poisoning for the alkylation reaction of 2-picoline with formaldehyde over Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 by co-feeding either acetic acid or 2,4,6-trimethylpyridine. It can be seen that the Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst was strongly deactivated by the addition of either acid or base compounds (Fig. S3), which suggested that the side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline is an acid-base synergistic catalysis process. The role of acid sites (mainly alkali cations) is to adsorb and stabilize 2-picoline, while the activation of formaldehyde and the carbon atom of the side chain of 2-picoline occur on the base sites (mainly the oxygen atoms of zeolite framework). Based on the above discussion, it can be inferred that the weakened acid sites and stronger basic sites provided by hollow ZSM-5 could enhance the catalytic activity. According to the observed correlation of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation activity with acid-base properties, we proposed the possible reaction pathway of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation with formaldehyde over cesium-modified ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 8 ). On the base sites, Formaldehyde would attack the methyl group of 2-picoline to form 2-vinylpyridine product and water. Meanwhile, formaldehyde would decompose into CO and H2 inevitably due to the strong base sites. Subsequently, 2-ethylpyridine would be formed by the hydrogenation of 2-vinylpyridine with hydrogen, which is generated by the decomposition of formaldehyde. On the other hand, the acid sites could adsorb and stabilize 2-picoline, whereas more acidity leads to direct methylation on the ring of 2-picoline and disproportionation, which facilitates the formation of more byproducts such as dimethyl pyridine and pyridine. 3.3.4 States of cesium species and oxygen species The states of cesium species of Cs-modified catalysts were investigated by means of XPS spectra of Cs 3d5/2, as shown in Fig. 9 a. All the samples showed two peaks, indicating the existence of two kinds of cesium species on these catalysts. The Cs 3d5/2 peaks centered at 724.2 eV was attributed to cesium ion as exchanged cation in the zeolite framework, while the other signal centered at 725.0 eV was assigned to Cs2O species [38–40]. The quantitative analyses of cesium species on the surface of different catalysts are summarized in Table 2. It can be seen that the fraction of Cs2O was observed as Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 > Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 > Cs-hZSM-5 > Cs-ZSM-5. Meanwhile, the fraction of cesium ions exhibited a reverse order. Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 showed the most cesium species in Cs2O (70.2 %) with the other 29.8 % in the form of Cs+ among these Cs-modified catalysts. The more Cs2O in Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 might be beneficial to the side-chain alkylation activity due to the synergistic effect of cesium ions and cesium oxides [11]. In the case of O 1s spectra for each sample (Fig. 9b), the peaks were also decomposed into two contributions. The O 1s peaks centered at 531.1eV was ascribed to the oxygen atoms of Cs2O crystal phase (Oα), and the one at higher binding energies of 531.7 eV was corresponding to framework oxygen (Oβ) [40,41]. The O 1s BE of the zeolite is directly correlated to the basicity of the framework oxygen, whose basic strength increases with decreasing of O 1s BE [42]. According to the XPS analysis (Table 2), Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the highest relative concentration ratios of Oα/Oβ (0.82) and accordingly the stronger basicity. 3.4 Effects of reaction conditions We investigated the effects of different reaction conditions using Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 as a catalyst. The effects of different reactant compositions (2-picoline/formaldehyde ratio), reaction temperatures and weight hourly space velocities (WHSV) were investigated. Fig. 10 a showed that the conversion of 2-picoline decreased with the increasing 2-picoline/formaldehyde (P/F) in the reactant feed from 0.5 to 2.0, which might be due to the reduced availability of the alkylating agent. Meanwhile, increasing the P/F value led to the enhanced selectivity towards the 2-VP product. This can be explained by the fact that the higher P/F increased the 2-picoline concentration within the zeolite micropores. Hence, HCHO has a greater chance to react with 2-picoline before further decomposition into CO and H2. As to the effects of reaction temperature (Fig. 10b), both the 2-picoline conversion and 2-VP selectivity increased from 270 to 320 °C, and then significantly decreased when the reaction temperature reached 370 °C. It should be due to the fact that 2-picoline stabilization on the catalyst became difficult at relatively high temperature (370 °C), thus HCHO self-decomposition occurred dominantly. Furthermore, the high reaction temperature is beneficial to the hydrogenation of 2-VP to form ethylbenzene [43]. Fig. 10 c showed the effect of WHSV on the catalytic reaction at 320 °C with 2-picoline/formaldehyde of 1.0. The space velocity increased from 0.5h−1 to 2.0 h−1 resulted in the decrease of 2-picoline conversion. It could be inferred that the residence time of the reactants and products on the catalyst surface would be shortened. Simultaneously, 2-VP selectivity was improved with the increasing space velocity. 3.5 Durability test The durability of Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 catalyst with time on stream was examined. As shown in Fig. 11 , Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 demonstrated excellent stability during 50 h in side-chain alkylation reaction of 2-picoline with formaldehyde (only 5.9 % 2-picoline conversion drop at the end of experiment). On the other hand, the 2-picoline conversion of Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 decreased from 44.1 to 25.3% after 50 h on reaction stream, meanwhile, the 2-VP selectivity decreased from 52.2 to 42.6%. Moreover, the deactivation constant kd (h−1) is used to determine the catalyst deactivation [45]. The kd values for Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 and Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 were 4.8 × 10-3 and 16.7 × 10-3 h−1, respectively. A higher deactivation constant for the Cs2O/Cs-ZSM-5 catalyst clearly indicated the rapid deactivation of this sample. These results highlight the promoting effect of hollow structure of ZSM-5 on improving reaction durability during 2-picoline side-chain alkylation reaction. 4 Conclusions In this paper, hollow ZSM-5 modified by cesium has been successfully fabricated, characterized and tested in the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation with formaldehyde, which exhibited superior activity. Among these catalysts, Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 achieved the highest 2-picoline conversion of 50.1 % with a 2-VP selectivity of 62.5 %. Furthermore, Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 exhibited the highest TOF and the lowest Ea value. The large BET surface area, increased mesoporous channels and harmonious acid-base property of the Cs modified hollow ZSM-5 catalysts endowed them with excellent catalytic performance. Moreover, the possible reaction pathway on Cs modified hollow ZSM-5 was proposed: on the base sites, formaldehyde would attack the methyl group of 2-picoline to form 2-vinylpyridine product and water, while the role of acid sites is to adsorb and stabilize 2-picoline. In addition, the durability test demonstrated that Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 exhibited excellent reaction durability during the side-chain alkylation process. These results suggest that Cs-modified hollow ZSM-5 catalyst is promising for potential industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Hollow ZSM-5 was successfully fabricated using a tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH) hydrothermal treatment with an “dissolution-recrystallization” process. The side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline with formaldehyde was studied on a series of cesium modified ZSM-5 catalysts. Among these catalysts, Cs2O/Cs-hollow ZSM-5 (Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5) was found to be the most effective catalyst, which exhibited not only the highest 2-picoline conversion (50.1 %), but also the highest TOF value (2.557 h−1) and the lowest Ea (39.7 kJ mol−1). Meanwhile, the Cs2O/Cs-hZSM-5 catalyst exhibited excellent reaction durability, which was related to the hollow structure of ZSM-5. In addition, the possible 2-picoline side-chain alkylation reaction pathways over cesium modified hollow ZSM-5 catalysts were proposed. The results of this study suggested that cesium modified hollow ZSM-5 is a promising candidate as a catalyst for the reaction of 2-picoline side-chain alkylation with formaldehyde in industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Cesium-modified hollow ZSM-5: Efficient acid-base catalyst for side-chain alkylation of 2-picoline with formaldehyde
